div.p: Tracy: Hi Nancy, Melvin.
Nancy: Hi Tracy.
Tracy: You two in the middle of something?
Nancy: Uh, no, Melvin was just leaving.
Melvin: Yeah, back to the old grindstone.
Tracy: Ah, yes, and that report you promised me yesterday? How’s that coming?
Melvin: It’s coming. I’ll get that right to you.
Nancy: How’s it going?
Tracy: Hi Nancy, good, how are you today?
Nancy: Oh, pretty good, pretty good.
Tracy: So are you busy?
Nancy: Not really, what’s up?
Tracy: Well, I know you’re fairly new as a hiring manager, but there’s a project we’d like you to take on.
Nancy: OK.
Tracy: The Department wants every office to streamline and improve its hiring process. I want you to make that happen for us.
Nancy: Oh wow, no pressure. What does streamline and improve mean?
Tracy: Well the average time it took last year to hire someone was 150 days.
Nancy: No wonder, did you hear about Foster?
Tracy: I did, and I can understand his frustration. It’s taking us so long to hire someone to help him.
Tracy: Anyways, the Office of Personnel Management wants us to whittle that 150 days down to no more than 80 days.
Nancy: Wow, that’s a big change.
Tracy: Oh it is. From five months to three months.
Nancy: Well, it sounds like a great idea, but how am I supposed to actually make that happen?
Tracy: Well, OPM has an 80-day process already worked out. And apparently 42% of the Federal Government is already doing this.

Tracy: So, I'm going to e-mail you some information on OPM's new 80-day process. And I'm hoping you can get your head around it really quickly, because I have a few questions, and maybe you can help clear that up.
Tracy: Would you be free later this afternoon?
Nancy: Sure, I'll keep an eye out for your emails and get started.
Tracy: OK, great! So just to be clear, let’s just do a little recap:
Tracy: I would like you to:
Tracy: identify the key steps in the 80-day process
Tracy: identify key decisions that you as a hiring manager should make before posting a job vacancy, and also to
Tracy: identify strategies for avoiding obstacles in the hiring process.
Nancy: OK, got it. Thanks.
Tracy: Great, thank you so much, Nancy.
Nancy: OK, see you later.
Tracy: Bye-bye.
